message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has liver cirrhosis and a liver mass, which suggests hepatocellular carcinoma. Sorafenib is the only targeted agent approved for advanced-stage hepatocellular carcinoma. Daclizumab, Palivizumab, and Abciximab are not indicated for hepatocellular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest hepatocellular carcinoma, and among the options, only Sorafenib is approved for advanced-stage hepatoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a liver mass and elevated alpha-fetoprotein, suggesting hepatoma (also known as hepatocellular carcinoma). Sorafenib is the only targeted agent that has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of advanced-stage hepatoma. Daclizumab, Palivizumab, and Abciximab are not indicated for the treatment of hepatoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and test results suggest that he is suffering from advanced-stage hepatoma. Among the options, only Sorafenib is approved for advanced-stage hepatoma. Daclizumab is used to prevent rejection in organ transplantation, Palivizumab is used to prevent respiratory syncytial virus infections in newborns, and Abciximab is used to prevent blood clotting during angioplasty.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation, including a liver mass, history of hepatitis B and cirrhosis, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, suggests hepatocellular carcinoma. Among the options, only Sorafenib is approved for advanced-stage hepatoma. Daclizumab is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis, Palivizumab is used for respiratory syncytial virus infection, and Abciximab is an antiplatelet agent used in certain cardiovascular procedures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation and high alpha fetoprotein levels suggest hepatocellular carcinoma. Among the options, only Sorafenib is approved for advanced-stage hepatocellular carcinoma. Daclizumab is used for multiple sclerosis, Palivizumab is used for respiratory syncytial virus, and Abciximab is used for cardiovascular disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a liver mass and elevated alpha fetoprotein levels, which are suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma. Sorafenib is the targeted agent approved for advanced-stage hepatoma. Daclizumab is an immunosuppressant used in transplant patients while Palivizumab is used to prevent respiratory syncytial virus infections. Abciximab is an antiplatelet agent used during percutaneous coronary interventions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest advanced-stage hepatoma. Among the options, only Sorafenib is approved for advanced-stage hepatoma. Daclizumab is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis, Palivizumab is used for respiratory syncytial virus, and Abciximab is used in the prevention of platelet aggregation during coronary interventions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of advanced-stage hepatoma, and the blood investigations show elevated alpha fetoprotein levels. Sorafenib is a targeted agent that is approved for advanced-stage hepatoma and has been shown to improve overall survival. The other options are not used to treat hepatoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation and lab values are highly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Sorafenib is the only targeted agent that is approved for advanced-stage HCC. The other options are monoclonal antibodies used in immunotherapy or anticoagulant agents.
